key_insight: A multimodal ML pipeline integrates heterogeneous clinical and operational data into a single, interpretable Early Warning Index that forecasts patient deterioration earlier and with actionable explanations.
problem_solved: Automates forecasting of in-hospital patient deterioration by overcoming inconsistent data formats and fragmented data streams, producing timely, interpretable risk assessments for clinicians and care managers.
method: Harmonize heterogeneous inputs (vitals, labs, notes, bed/flow/operational data) into a unified feature representation and time-aligned windows.
Fuse multimodal signals with a predictive model optimized for real-time scoring and calibration, emphasizing interpretability (e.g., sparse models or post-hoc explanation methods).
Validate on hospital workflows with clinically relevant metrics and produce an easy-to-read Early Warning Index output for downstream triage/alerts.
impact: Provides a practical blueprint for ML practitioners to build deployable, interpretable early-warning systems in hospitals — reducing alarm fatigue and enabling proactive clinical interventions with measurable performance and operational benefits.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing data sources → harmonization → multimodal fusion → Early Warning Index output
Time-series chart of patient vitals with overlayed risk trajectory and predicted deterioration window
Feature importance/SHAP-style explanation panel highlighting top drivers of risk for a sample patient
Dashboard mockup of real-time alerts, risk scores, and suggested clinician actions
paper_title: Early Warning Index for Patient Deteriorations in Hospitals
paper_authors: Dimitris Bertsimas, Yu Ma, Kimberly Villalobos Carballo, Gagan Singh, Michal Laskowski
